name: apple
unsafe_signs: Large soft spots on the skin.
tips: Store apples in the refrigerator, ideally in a breathable or perforated bag.
Keep them away from bananas, which emit ethylene and accelerate ripening.
Leave apples whole until use—cut apples brown quickly when exposed to air.

name: avocado
unsafe_signs: A sour or off smell when opened.
Visible mold near the stem or on the surface.
tips: Let firm avocados ripen at room temperature before refrigerating.
Store ripe avocados in the refrigerator to slow further softening.
Keep cut avocados wrapped tightly or with lemon to reduce browning.

name: banana
tips: Store bananas at room temperature for even ripening.
Refrigerate ripe bananas to slow browning—the skins may darken but the fruit stays firm.
Avoid sealing bananas in airtight bags, which trap moisture and accelerate spoilage.

name: blueberry
unsafe_signs: Visible mold fuzz on the berries.
tips: Store blueberries unwashed in the refrigerator.
Wash only right before eating to prevent moisture-related spoilage.
Remove spoiled berries promptly to prevent mold spread.

name: carrot
unsafe_signs: Soft rot or black mold spots.
tips: Store carrots in a ventilated bag in the refrigerator.
Keep them dry to avoid surface slime.
Remove green tops if present, as they draw moisture from the carrot.

name: cauliflower
unsafe_signs: Black mold on florets or stem.
tips: Store cauliflower whole in the refrigerator for best longevity.
Keep it dry—moisture encourages mold.
Small brown spots are usually cosmetic and can be trimmed away.

name: cucumber
tips: Store cucumbers in the crisper drawer to avoid cold injury.
Keep them dry and away from areas of high humidity.
Do not store directly against very cold refrigerator walls.

name: grape
unsafe_signs: Mold growth on stems or fruit.
tips: Store grapes unwashed in a breathable bag in the refrigerator.
Wash only before eating to prevent excess moisture.
Remove spoiled grapes to prevent mold spreading.

name: lemon
unsafe_signs: Soft, squishy spots on the peel.
tips: Store lemons in the refrigerator for best shelf life.
Keep them dry—moisture encourages mold.
Avoid airtight bags, which trap humidity.

name: onion
unsafe_signs: Wet, soft rot under the skin.
Black or green mold between layers.
tips: Store onions in a cool, dark, well-ventilated place.
Avoid plastic bags—onions need airflow.
Keep onions separate from potatoes, which accelerate spoilage.
